article.description:
Chuck Davis had 19 points and nine
rebounds to lift No. 15 Alabama to a season-opening 64-58 victory
over Miami of Ohio on Tuesday night in the first round of the
Preseason NIT.
article.headline: Alabama wears down Miami, holds on for win
article.linkText: Alabama wears down Miami, holds on for win
article.story: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. (AP) -- Mark Gottfried wasn't particularly impressed with Alabama's season-opening win. But the Crimson Tide (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 15 AP) did get steady performances from its returning starters and a dunking display from a top freshman Tuesday night in a 64-58 victory over Miami of Ohio in the first round of the Preseason NIT. "We're not very good," the Tide coach said. "We've got to get a lot better. Games like tonight expose you because they help you recognize where you've got to get better. Defensively, we've got to get better." They'd better do it quickly. Alabama will host No. 12 Memphis, a 79-52 winner over Wisconsin-Milwaukee, on Thursday night in the second round. Chuck Davis had 19 points and nine rebounds while Ronald Steele and Jermareo Davidson finished with 10 points apiece for the Tide, which had to replace leading scorers Kennedy Winston and Earnest Shelton. Freshman Alonzo Gee supplied the biggest highlights with four fast-break dunks to spark a 16-5 run that gave Alabama a 56-44 lead midway through the second half. It was one of the few stretches where the Tide managed to control the tempo with defensive pressure against the RedHawks. "The press has been good to us in the past," Steele said. "We're going to have to depend on it. Alonzo really came in and gave us a spark off the bench. We got a couple of easy baskets, and I think that was probably the difference in the game." Gee, whose only points came on those dunks, was only a little surprised by his debut. "I didn't think I would get as many dunks as I did," the 6-foot-6 forward said. "I expected one, though." Miami cut it to 59-58 with 2:08 left on two free throws by Doug Penno to cap a 12-3 run but couldn't score again. Davis hit a long jumper and the RedHawks (0-1) were unable to get an open look at the basket in the closing minutes, missing their final four shots. Steele hit two free throws with 51 seconds left and Jean Felix made one of two after a steal to close the scoring. "Bama kind of wore us down in the second half," Miami coach Charlie Coles said. William Hatcher led Miami with 13 points, all in the first half, and had eight assists. Michael Bramos scored 12 points, Nathan Peavy had 11 and Tim Pollitz 10. Peavy also had 11 rebounds. "We knew that we wouldn't be able to outrun them or outjump them, but we wanted to be scrappy and hard-nosed and play as hard as we could," Hatcher said. "We don't want to take this as a moral victory but it gives us a lot of confidence." The game was tied at 31-all at halftime. The Tide led by as many as seven points before Hatcher sparked an 11-0 run with two 3-pointers and eight points for the RedHawks. The Tide improved to 38-1 in home openers at Coleman Coliseum, including 12 straight victories. It was the first game at Coleman since it underwent a $28 million renovation. Alabama was 24-8 last season but lost in the first round of the NCAA Tournament.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
